channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Hacking MPs recall James Murdoch
item.description: News International chairman James Murdoch is to face more questions from MPs on the Commons culture committee about phone hacking.

item.title: Explosions and gunfire rock Kabul
item.description: The Taliban say they are behind ongoing attacks in the Afghan capital, with blasts targeting the embassy district and one person killed by a suicide bomber in western Kabul.

item.title: Miliband heckled by union members
item.description: Ed Miliband is heckled at the TUC conference by workers angry at his decision not to back public sector strikes over pension reforms.

item.title: Top MPs at risk in Commons cull
item.description: Some of the most high-profile MPs in Parliament face seeing their seats disappear as part of a far-reaching shake-up of England and Northern Ireland's electoral map.

item.title: Merkel bids to allay Greece fears
item.description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel tries to calm nerves over possible Greek default, saying the eurozone bloc must stay together.

item.title: UK inflation rate rises to 4.5%
item.description: The rate of Consumer Prices Index inflation rose to 4.5% in August from 4.4% the month before, official figures show.

item.title: Soldiers help Briton kidnap hunt
item.description: Extra police and soldiers are sent to the area in Kenya where a British holidaymaker was shot and killed and his wife kidnapped.

item.title: 'Moderate Islam' to guide Libya
item.description: Libya will be ruled as a democracy based on "moderate Islam", says the head of the interim authorities in his first speech in Tripoli since Col Gaddafi was ousted.

item.title: Men in court on slavery charges
item.description: Four men are due in court later charged with slavery offences relating to people found at a travellers' site in Bedfordshire.

item.title: Gunmen ambush Pakistan school bus
item.description: Gunmen ambush a school bus on the outskirts of the north-western Pakistani city of Peshawar, killing at least five children, police say.

item.title: OECD warns over tuition fees hike
item.description: A report reveals that UK students pay a greater share of the cost of their university education than students in most other developed countries.

item.title: Fox 'proud' of UK defence firms
item.description: Defence Secretary Liam Fox is expected to give strong backing to UK arms manufacturers in a speech at a major defence exhibition in London.

item.title: Fatherhood 'lowers testosterone'
item.description: Men appear to be biologically wired to care for their babies, say researchers who have discovered levels of testosterone go down after becoming a dad.

item.title: Olympic shopping centre is opened
item.description: A Â£1.45bn shopping centre which will form the gateway to the 2012 Olympic Park opens in east London.

item.title: Sellers' housing market 'gloom'
item.description: Fourteen homes were sold per UK estate agent in the three months to August - the lowest total for over two years, a survey says.

item.title: Italy's borrowing costs increase
item.description: Italy's borrowing costs on five-year bonds hits a new high, reflecting a continuing lack of investor confidence in the country's finances.

item.title: Blagging firms 'get away with it'
item.description: Blagging of personal data goes far beyond the media but debt collectors and other firms are getting away with it, warns the information commissioner.

item.title: Move towards new monthly benefit
item.description: Many benefits could be paid monthly under government plans to shake-up the welfare system and introduce the Universal Credit.

item.title: Fish oils block chemotherapy drug
item.description: Fats found in fish oil supplements can stop chemotherapy working, according to researchers in the Netherlands.

item.title: Baby death hospital given warning
item.description: The NHS trust at the centre of a police investigation into baby deaths has been issued with a rare warning notice by the Care Quality Commission watchdog.

item.title: Pupils face 'illegal exclusions'
item.description: Some schools in England are "acting illegally or unscrupulously" by excluding pupils by unofficial means, the Centre for Social Justice think tank says.

item.title: Teacher strike ballot result due
item.description: The results of a strike ballot among members of the teaching union Ucac over pensions will be revealed later.

item.title: Skynet seeks idle computer power
item.description: Idle home computers are being sought to help analyse mountains of astronomical data set to be produced by new telescopes.

item.title: Legal action on college book plan
item.description: Groups representing authors have issued a lawsuit against five US universities which plan to open digital libraries of books scanned by Google.

item.title: Researchers plan for city living
item.description: Different urbanisation policies have varying impacts on a region's ecosystem services such as flood mitigation and food production, researchers report.

item.title: 2012 Games 'toughest for cheats'
item.description: The scientist in charge of anti-doping at next years London Olympics says the games will be the toughest yet for cheats.

item.title: India actress banned for 'affair'
item.description: Producers in southern India impose a three-year film ban on actress Nikhita Thukral over an alleged affair with another actor.

item.title: Campaign to save Roald Dahl hut
item.description: Roald Dahl's family launches a campaign to save the hut in which author wrote many of his best-loved stories.

item.title: The darkness of Dahl
item.description: James and the Giant Peach is 50. In it there is death and cruelty, so why was Roald Dahl so dark?

item.title: The real Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy
item.description: How firmly is Le Carre's classic spy story rooted in reality?

item.title: Lawes given two-match suspension
item.description: England lock Courtney Lawes is suspended for two matches for "recklessly striking" Argentina's Mario Ledesma with his knee on Saturday.

item.title: Sportsday Live - breaking sports news as it happens
item.description: Sportsday features the climax of the County Championship, Rugby World Cup latest, football gossip, plus more.

item.title: Aggression is the key - Djokovic
item.description: US Open champion Novak Djokovic says a more aggressive approach is key to his excellent form - but insists he is not invincible after beating Rafael Nadal.

item.title: Europa snub annoys Van der Vaart
item.description: Tottenham's Rafael van der Vaart says he is annoyed at being left out of the club's Europa League squad.

item.title: Benfica v Man Utd
item.description: Rio Ferdinand is left out of Manchester United's 19-man party for their opening Champions League fixture against Benfica on Wednesday.

item.title: Walliams' Thames swim completed
item.description: Comedian David Walliams says he is relieved after swimming 140 miles of the River Thames for charity.

item.title: Six teens charged over M1 fire
item.description: Six teenagers have been charged over a fire that closed a stretch of the M1 in north London in April.

item.title: Call for more teacher flexibility
item.description: Scotland's education system needs more flexibility to help teachers do their jobs better, a major investigation has recommended.

item.title: Student sentenced for flag racism
item.description: A student at St Andrews University who was found guilty of a racist breach of the peace after he insulted the flag of Israel is given community service.

item.title: 8m cigarettes are seized at port
item.description: Eight million cigarettes worth 3.1m euros, which were seized at Dublin port on Monday, are believed to have been on the way to Northern Ireland.

item.title: End celibacy now - Bishop Daly
item.description: The former Bishop of Derry Dr Edward Daly has called for an end to clerical celibacy.

item.title: Some pupils 'don't learn enough'
item.description: Children at a "significant minority" of primary schools are not learning enough through a flagship policy to raise standards, inspectors says.

item.title: Plant halts production for week
item.description: BBC Wales learns that steelmaker Tata - which employs 7,000 in Wales - is to temporarily halt production at its tinplate works in Llanelli.

item.title: ANC to challenge 'hate song' ban
item.description: South Africa's ruling African National Congress (ANC) party is to appeal against a high court ruling banning the anti-apartheid song Shoot the Boer.

item.title: Kenya pipeline fire kills dozens
item.description: At least 75 people are killed in a petrol pipeline blast and fire in Kenya's capital Nairobi, the Red Cross says, as flames tear through a nearby shanty town.

item.title: Japan PM in nuclear restart call
item.description: Yoshihiko Noda calls for nuclear plants halted after the Fukushima crisis to be restarted, but pledges a shift away from nuclear in the long term.

item.title: Australia to hold media inquiry
item.description: Australia's government says it is to set up a wide-ranging inquiry into the media, after the News of the World phone hacking scandal in the UK.

item.title: 'Breivik party' suffers in vote
item.description: The anti-immigrant Progress Party once favoured by right-wing extremist Anders Behring Breivik loses a third of its vote in local elections in Norway.

item.title: Incredible Djokovic wins US Open
item.description: Novak Djokovic beats defending champion Rafael Nadal in an epic final to win his first US Open and third Grand Slam title of 2011.

item.title: Argentina bus and trains collide
item.description: A bus and two trains collide in the Argentine capital, Buenos Aires, killing at least six people and injuring dozens, some seriously, police say.

item.title: Brazil judge stops airport work
item.description: A judge in Brazil orders work on a new airport terminal in Sao Paulo to stop, dealing a blow to World Cup and Olympics expansion plans.

item.title: Iran 'to free' US spy-case hikers
item.description: Two Americans jailed for spying in Iran will be released in two days, Iranian President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad tells US news network NBC.

item.title: Turkey's PM to outline Egypt plan
item.description: Turkish PM Recep Tayyip Erdogan is to address the Arab League, where he will give details of support for transition to democracy in Egypt.

item.title: Torrential rains cripple Karachi
item.description: Pakistan's commercial capital Karachi is paralysed by floods as heavy rain lashes southern Sindh province, bringing misery to millions in rural areas.

item.title: Man held over Delhi blast claim
item.description: Indian police arrest a man for sending an email in the name of an Indian militant group and claiming responsibility for last week's bomb attack in Delhi.

item.title: Republicans battle in TV debate
item.description: Rick Perry is attacked on the issues of Social Security, his record as Texas governor, and immigration as Republican White House contenders hold their latest TV debate.

item.title: Obama sends job plan to Congress
item.description: Republicans object as the White House says it plans to pay for its $450bn jobs plan with taxes on oil firms, fund managers and corporate jet owners.

item.title: In pictures: Kenyan pipeline blast
item.description: Explosion and fire at an oil pipeline in Kenya

item.title: In pictures: Tajik village life
item.description: Life 20 years after independence

item.title: Day in pictures
item.description: Photos from around the world on 12 September

item.title: In pictures: 9/11 anniversary
item.description: The US commemorates 10th anniversary

item.title: In pictures: UK services mark 9/11 anniversary
item.description: Families of British victims attended services

item.title: Week in pictures: 3-9 September 2011
item.description: A selection of pictures from this week's news

item.title: In pictures: Rain and floods in South Asia
item.description: Monsoon chaos in South Asia

item.title: In pictures: Rugby World Cup begins in New Zealand
item.description: Rugby World Cup kicks off in New Zealand

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: Chancellor George Osborne welcomed the Independent Commission on Banking's final report.

item.title: VIDEO: Headcam footage of bomb defusion
item.description: For the first time, the Ministry of Defence has allowed the work of specialist bomb disposal teams in Afghanistan to be shown.

item.title: VIDEO: Inside Japan's exclusion zone
item.description: Six months on from Japan's nuclear crisis, science correspondent David Shukman enters the Fukushima exclusion zone.

item.title: VIDEO: Behind bars at the Maze
item.description: The former Maze prison opens its doors to the public

item.title: VIDEO: 'Mega mall' opens for business
item.description: It is the biggest urban shopping mall anywhere in Europe and on Tuesday, Westfield Stratford City opens for business.

item.title: VIDEO: Soldiers help Briton kidnap hunt
item.description: The Kenyan army has now joined in the search for the British tourist Judith Tebbutt who was kidnapped at a luxury resort near the border with Somalia.

item.title: VIDEO: Britain battered by high winds
item.description: Parts of Britain are being battered by the remnants of Hurricane Katia with Scotland, Wales and the north-east of England bearing the brunt of 70mph winds and heavy rainfall.

item.title: VIDEO: The town where Gaddafi's flag flies
item.description: Few areas in Libya remain loyal to fugitive former leader Col Gaddafi, but forces supporting the country's transitional authority have yet to take control of the town of Bani Walid.

item.title: VIDEO: Rough sleepers 'sold as slaves'
item.description: Some of the most vulnerable members of society, among them rough sleepers, are being imprisoned against their will and sold for as little as Â£100, a BBC London investigation reveals.

item.title: Should Hitler's Wall be preserved?
item.description: Should France restore its Nazi coast defences?

item.title: 'Wi-fi refugees' shelter in West Virginia mountains
item.description: The 'wi-fi casualties' sheltering in the mountains of West Virginia

item.title: How penguins find a perfect partner
item.description: What makes one bird attractive to another?

item.title: Could a robot be conscious?
item.description: Could robots really be viewed as conscious?

item.title: The fight for India's water supply
item.description: Big business and technology join the fight for rural water supplies

item.title: Constituency changes: The implications
item.description: A look at what constituency changes could mean for England and Northern Ireland

item.title: Community or custody? A tough question
item.description: What is the most effective deterrent for criminals?
